items.title: Apple lists all apps it removed alongside TikTok in the U.S.
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Apple issued a statement listing apps removed due to the TikTok shutdown.
- Affected apps include TikTok, CapCut, Lemon8, and Marvel Snap.
- The removal is due to the Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act, effective January 19, 2025.
- Users in the U.S. won’t receive updates or be able to download these apps.
- The Supreme Court upheld the law that prompted the app removals.
keywords: Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act

items.title: TikTok goes dark in the US
items.author: Kyle Wiggers, Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- TikTok has been banned in the U.S. following a federal law, rendering it inaccessible for millions of Americans.
- The ban was enacted around 10:30 p.m. Eastern, and the app was also removed from Apple and Google Play stores.
- TikTok suggests the ban may be temporary and has expressed hope for a resolution with President-elect Donald Trump once he takes office.
- The ban stems from bipartisan legislation requiring TikTok's owner, ByteDance, to sell the app amid concerns over Chinese surveillance.
- The Supreme Court upheld the law before the ban was enacted, leaving its implementation to the next administration.
- Alternative Chinese-owned apps like RedNote and Lemon8 have gained popularity as users search for alternatives.

items.title: Perplexity AI submits bid to merge with TikTok
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- Perplexity AI has submitted a bid to merge with TikTok US amid a potential ban of the app in the US.
- The bid aims to create a new entity that combines Perplexity, TikTok US, and new equity partners, allowing investors in ByteDance to retain their equity.
- A law requiring ByteDance to sell TikTok or face a ban is set to take effect on January 19, the last day of President Biden's term.
- President-elect Trump may grant TikTok a 90-day extension to avoid the ban, while TikTok states it could 'go dark' without assurances from the Biden administration.
- Despite interest from multiple buyers, ByteDance maintains it does not intend to sell TikTok, viewing the merger proposal as a potential workaround.

items.title: FTC says partnerships like Microsoft-OpenAI raise antitrust concerns
items.summary:
- The FTC issued a report on January 18, 2025, highlighting competitive issues in big tech partnerships with generative AI developers, specifically mentioning Microsoft-OpenAI and Amazon-Google with Anthropic.
- FTC Chair Lina Khan stated these partnerships could create lock-in effects, deprive startups of AI inputs, and disclose sensitive information, undermining fair competition.
- The report raises concerns about cloud service providers' influence on AI development, access to computing resources, increased switching costs, and unfair access to sensitive information.

items.title: What we know about the TikTok ban
items.author: Cody Corrall
items.summary:
- The U.S. Supreme Court upheld a law that will prohibit TikTok in the U.S., effectively banning the app starting Sunday.
- American users are transitioning to RedNote, a Chinese app, which has surged in popularity and is now the No. 1 free app on the U.S. App Store.
- Duolingo reports a 216% increase in U.S. users learning Mandarin as TikTok users seek alternatives amid the impending ban.

items.title: Once high-flying proptech startups Divvy Homes and EasyKnock are the latest to struggle
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo, Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Divvy Homes and EasyKnock are recent casualties in the struggling proptech sector.
- Investment in U.S. real estate startups dropped from $11.1 billion in 2021 to $3.7 billion in 2022.
- Divvy Homes is being acquired by Maymont Homes, a division of Brookfield Properties, amid ongoing layoffs.
- EasyKnock shut down after facing multiple lawsuits and being declared insolvent.
- Both companies struggled due to rising interest rates hindering their business models of purchasing homes.

items.title: DOJ confirms arrested US Army soldier is linked to AT&T and Verizon hacks
items.author: Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- U.S. Army soldier Cameron John Wagenius arrested on December 20 for unlawfully transferring confidential phone records.
- Arrest tied to a massive theft of phone records from AT&T and Verizon linked to breaches at Snowflake.
- Wagenius faces charges related to earlier indictments of hackers Connor Moucka and John Binns, involving significant data theft from multiple companies.
- Prosecutors confirmed overlapping evidence and legal issues related to the cases.
- Arrest publicized after Wagenius claimed access to sensitive call logs as part of extortion threats.
- He remains in custody in Washington state after a detention order issued on January 8.

items.title: TikTok says it will go dark Sunday unless Biden offers ‘definitive statement’
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- TikTok claims it may go dark on January 19 unless President Biden provides definitive reassurances against a ban.
- The Supreme Court upheld a law that could effectively ban TikTok unless ByteDance sells the app, which they refuse to do.
- The Biden administration has not changed its position, leaving TikTok's future uncertain as the incoming Trump administration is expected to address the issue.

items.title: How victims of PowerSchool’s data breach helped each other investigate ‘massive’ hack
items.summary:
- On January 7, PowerSchool notified that many schools were victims of a data breach discovered on December 28.
- Hackers accessed sensitive data including Social Security numbers and medical records from over 60 million students and 18,000 schools.
- Romy Backus, from American School of Dubai, led the investigation to determine the extent of the breach for her school.
- School workers utilized email listservs for information sharing, leading to a collaborative response to understand the breach's impact.
- Backus developed a guide detailing the breach and shared it with other PowerSchool administrators, which went viral within the community.
- The PowerSchool incident highlighted the need for better information sharing in the education sector regarding cybersecurity.

items.title: EV startup Canoo files for bankruptcy and ceases operations
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- Canoo, a seven-year-old electric vehicle startup, has filed for bankruptcy and will cease operations immediately.
- The company is undergoing a Chapter 7 bankruptcy process in the Delaware Bankruptcy Court, owing over $164 million and claiming around $126 million in assets.
- Canoo struggled to secure funding, including from the U.S. Department of Energy, and faced multiple executive departures in 2024, leading to layoffs and idled operations in Oklahoma.
- Canoo has been one of several EV startups to go bankrupt after merging with a SPAC, following companies like Electric Last Mile Solutions and Lordstown Motors.
- The startup, which once aimed to sell electric vans to notable clients like Walmart, failed to deliver substantial product volumes after going public in 2020.

items.title: Amazon suspends US drone deliveries following crash at testing facility
items.summary:
- Amazon has paused testing of its delivery drones after two models crashed at a testing facility in Pendleton, Oregon, during rainy weather in December 2024.
- The incidents included a prior collision in September due to simultaneous test launches caused by a propeller failure test.
- Drone deliveries are suspended in Texas and Arizona pending a software update; similar programs have faced multiple setbacks, including the departure of key executives and the cessation of operations in California.

items.title: ChatGPT’s head of product will testify in the US government’s case against Google
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Nick Turley, head of product for ChatGPT, will testify for the U.S. government in its antitrust case against Google.
- The DOJ aims to prove competitors face barriers to entry and seeks to identify penalties for Google following a previous court ruling on its monopoly in search.
- Google has subpoenaed OpenAI, aiming for documents related to Turley's testimony and disputing the amount of evidence provided by OpenAI.

items.title: Netradyne snags $90M at $1.35B valuation to expand smart dashcams for commercial fleets
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Netradyne raises $90 million in Series D funding at a pre-money valuation of $1.35 billion, led by Point72 Private Investments.
- The funding aims to expand their smart dashcam technology for commercial fleets, reducing accidents by around 50%.
- The company has accumulated over 18 billion miles of driving data to improve driver safety and compliance scores.
- Netradyne plans to enhance its product offerings using generative AI, focusing on driving models and autonomous driving technology.
- The startup is GDPR-compliant and aims to ensure driver privacy in its operations.

items.title: Perplexity acquires Read.cv, a social media platform for professionals
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Perplexity, an AI-powered search engine, has acquired Read.cv, a social media platform for professionals.
- Read.cv will wind down operations starting Friday, and users can transfer their data until May 16.
- The acquisition marks Read.cv's transition to joining Perplexity’s design and engineering team.
- Users can continue to manage their “.cv” domains after migrating them to Hello.cv starting January 31.
- Perplexity has previously acquired Carbon and Spellwise, and had been increasing its focus on corporate functionality.

items.title: TikTok ban: How to download your videos and data
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- The Supreme Court has upheld a TikTok ban, prompting users to back up their videos before the app is potentially shut down on Sunday.
- To download a video, go to your profile, select the video, and tap 'Save video'.
- For bulk downloads, third-party apps exist but may have varying reliability.
- Users can request their TikTok data via Settings > Account > Download your data, with formats including TXT or JSON, but not all data may be available due to privacy concerns.
- Downloaded data will be available for four days after TikTok notifies users that it's ready.

items.title: AI startup Character AI tests games on the web
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Character AI is testing games on its web apps to enhance user engagement.
- Games available for paid subscribers and select free users; includes 'Speakeasy' and 'War of Words'.
- 'Speakeasy' involves making the chatbot say a word without using five given words.
- 'War of Words' features dueling with AI characters, judged by an AI referee.
- Company aims to create a more entertaining experience for users.
- Changes in leadership include hiring a new chief product officer and an interim CEO.
- The introduction of games aims to position Character AI as a wholesome entertainment platform.
- Other platforms like YouTube and Netflix use games for engagement, Character AI seeks similar outcomes.

items.title: Bluesky saw 17x increase in moderation reports in 2024 after rapid growth
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Bluesky published its 2024 moderation report, noting a significant increase in user reports.
- There were 6.48 million reports, a 17x increase from 358,000 in 2023, mostly for harassment and trolling.
- The platform added over 23 million users, largely from former Twitter/X users.
- Bluesky's moderation team grew to about 100, providing psychological counseling for moderators.
- Automation helped reduce report processing time significantly, but introduced false positives.
- Most moderation reports were for anti-social behavior, spam, and misleading content.
- 93,076 users submitted 205,000 appeals regarding moderation decisions.
- The company complied with 146 out of 238 legal requests, mostly related to law enforcement.

items.title: ChatGPT’s newest feature lets users assign it traits like ‘chatty’ and ‘Gen Z’
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI launched a new feature for ChatGPT allowing users to customize chatbot traits like 'Chatty' and 'Gen Z'.
- The update includes a new user interface for the custom instructions menu, rolling out first on ChatGPT.com and Windows desktop, with mobile and MacOS versions to follow.
- Users can now specify preferred names, professions, and traits for ChatGPT, enhancing personalization.
- This feature is not available yet for EU users.
- OpenAI aims for moderation on custom instructions to adhere to terms of use, maintaining user interaction quality.

items.title: TikTok CEO responds to Trump, thanks him for trying to solve US ban
items.author: Shou Zi Chew
items.summary:
- TikTok CEO Shou Zi Chew responded to comments from Donald Trump about the Supreme Court ruling on the TikTok ban in the U.S.  
- Chew expressed gratitude to Trump for his commitment to finding a solution that keeps TikTok available in the U.S., calling it a stand for the First Amendment.  
- Currently uncertain if TikTok will disable the app in the U.S. or wait for negotiations with the Trump administration for a resolution.

items.title: SpaceX and Blue Origin must investigate this week’s big rocket tests, FAA says
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- The FAA requires SpaceX and Blue Origin to conduct a ‘mishap investigation’ following recent rocket test failures.
- SpaceX's Starship exploded during its seventh test flight, caused by over-pressurization from excess gas.
- Blue Origin's New Glenn rocket launched successfully but the booster exploded during return landing.
- FAA has to sign off on corrections before either company can resume flights.
